Hi Priyatharshan, 

Can you use your full name here?

From https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages 

All commit messages must include a "Signed-off-by" line, which indicates that you the contributor have agreed to the Developer Certificate of Origin (see below). This line must include the full name you commonly use, often a given name and a family name or surname. (ok: Sam Samuelsson, Robert A. Heinlein; not ok: xXthorXx, Sam, RAH)

Thanks!

Hi, Thanks for the info.

But "Priyatharshan P" is my full name.

The problem is really more fundamental than 'single host' vs 'multi-host'.  The problem is anytime we want to activate a software update which could be applicable for multiple devices.

I don't think creating a new interface called 'biosUpdate' is the right approach because it doesn't solve the general problem.  BIOS is really specific to x86 architectures anyhow.
By Multiple devices do you mean Multiple CPLD's / Bridge IC's, etc in a single host?
VRs, CPLDs, GPUs, Intel MEs, IBM OCCs, even BMCs in some multi-BMC designs.  There are lots of cases where a single firmware image may be applicable to multiple devices in the system.

So there are lot of cases we are haiving muliple devices in the systems.One thought is we can have a JSON config file that describes the number of devices associated with the system.

A dafult JSON file will be provided in phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt, and the platform specific JSON file should be provided from receipe layer.

The sample config file will look something like below:

host1
{
   VR:3
   CPLD:2
   GPU:1
   Intel_ME:2
},
host2
{
   VR:2
   CPLD:1
   GPU:3
   Intel_ME:1
}
...

Kindly share your comments on this.

I would prefer if it were either based on Inventory or if the software update software made that determination, likely based on Inventory.

It isn't as simple as just "there are 2 CPLDs so any CPLD update can be applied anywhere".  There might be 2 CPLDs which serve a different purpose and the ExtendedVersion field is suppose to be used to make a determination as to which CPLDs an image might be appropriate for.  (CPLDs were used as an example here.)

Agree, we can make software-manager to determine all the available devices from inventory that needs firmware update. Currently, updating the design document which uses the inventory. Need clarifications considering couple of approaches.

1. Use of ExtendedVersion:
 a) How does the ExtendedVersion be used to determine which device needs an firmware update considering multiple device scenario.
 b) Could the ExtendedVersion value in MANIFEST file be mapped with inventory objects.
 c) Do we expect to update the firmware image for all the devices that matches the ExtendedVersion.
 d) Is the ExtendedVersion value in the MANIFEST file be factroy ship out or to be modified by the user before each update.

2. As an alternate, can create new interfaces for each of the object identified from the inventory. Then user can sets the new "biosUpdate" property to "true" for devices that needs firmware update. After successfull activation the image will be deleted at the end.
Is this a compile-time option, or how would the phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt app have access to this number to create the hostX d-bus interfaces?

This is the compile time option only. We have mentioned this OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES in the machine conf files for each platform. So All the application can access the OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES in the bb/bb.append files. OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES default value is "0" for single host.

Could a system support a different number of host instances? Are there any concerns that for example there is a meta-yosemitev2 configuration with 2 hosts and one with 4 hosts, or if in the future more host instances are supported?
Yes , the system will support for a different number of host instances.

I don't think that we should create software/<entity> subdirectories unless we get sign-off from the Redfish implementation.  No other firmware update subsystems have done this and the Redfish / WebUI code doesn't know to interrogate subdirectories.

What specifically is solved by having a subdirectory?  Can that be solved by an association instead?
If they don't, should the Redfish API return an error because nothing was updated, or success and the user can figure out themselves?
Yes, If no host is selected for bios update, The code will throw "No host is added for update".

Again, this is a more fundamental problem.

The image should really only be deleted when "there are no more entities for which this image could be applied but is not yet applied".  This is really an implementation flaw in the single-host implementation and not an interface change.

With openbmc adopting Redfish, we'll need this property to be available in the Redfish schema. Are there any reasons not to use the BiosUpdate value you list below? (you mentioned that it could be considered). Perhaps also you could investigate to see if the DMTF has already solved how to select resources for parallel updates.
Since this is mentioned to support firmware other than BIOS we might want another file name / title.  Not sure what though.
suggest being consistent with capitalization here: BIOS
EM may or may not be where all inventory lives.  Avoid referencing EM specifically since that is an implementation of *some* inventory objects.

I'm not following what this is referring to.  I don't find anything in phosphor-dbus-interfaces having a property Class.  If you're proposing something new it needs to be documented there as well.  If you're using something that EM is providing due to some JSON files, we need to get that documented.

I have created a WIP patch for this approach2 with the below link:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt/+/37448

Kindly review this doc and share your thoughts of both approaches.

There are concerns listed in the original doc where this new property to select which instance to update does not map to redfish. The direction is to get all the user interfaces into redfish instead of the custom REST apis.
I don't understand this sentence.  The user should not be responsible for knowing which devices a firmware image can apply to.  Is that what you're suggesting?

@Adriana, You already suggested this new property to select which instance to update does not map to redfish. But I think the user should have the knowledge or should select which are the devices are getting updated.Any thoughts?
@Adriana, Could you please update on the above.

> The user should not be responsible for knowing which devices a firmware image can apply to.  Is that what you're suggesting?

What I understand is that this doc is trying to solve how to selectively update a subset of items, in this case the bios, by allowing the user to select which of the multiple bios instances should be updated and leaving the other bios instances untouched.

> You already suggested this new property to select which instance to update does not map to redfish. But I think the user should have the knowledge or should select which are the devices are getting updated

I'm just pointing out that any interface or property should be mapped to redfish, since that's what bmcweb and openbmc in general supports as an external interface.
@Adriana, are you ok with this approach?  I'd tend to prefer we improve Activation to handle multiple items, but I don't have a good way to do it.

Agree that we should try to fit this in the current Activation interface. Maybe some way via expanding the inventory associations, i think it's been discussed to use the inventory items as triggers. Need to think about this some more.

I don't like this initial proposal but I think it is almost workable.

1. Software is intended to be a very generic name and not specific to "firmware".  I don't see any reason to restrict the multi-item update process to "firmware" either by calling it "fw update".

2. What we're really doing here is extending Activation so that the Activation is applied across a set of Inventory items.  I would suggest instead we create an interface maybe called ActivationItems (Elements?) which has a property : Items type=array<object_path> and maybe a method : AddItem(object_path).  The object_paths will reference the Inventory item to be updated.  When the activation is done the the update code will apply to all the applicable Inventory objects in the Items array.  We may need a signal for failed updates, especially in the case where the update image does not apply to the item.

Ideally, I'd like to see Activation refactored in a way where it can support a direct relationship between the SoftwareVersion and the Inventory item(s) to be updated.  I think there are some cases where you'll want to do an update to all the devices and some cases where you'll want to do the update one at a time but still without deleting the update at the end.  In my mind, the default behavior of the system should be to *not* delete an update for which there still exists an Inventory item that the update *could* apply to, unless the user explicitly Delete's the update.
That, to me, is a pretty minor disadvantage.  Isn't there anything we can do to fix it?
I'm not convinced I understand this section.  Is this a requirement or a design or just some background?
This is the requirement to get the devices/hosts list from the BMC inventory.

I definitely need more words in this document.  I sort of understand what you're saying from your response but a single headline "BMC Inventory Management" without any words related "Inventory" doesn't really tell me what is going on.

"Software manager" isn't a term that has been defined up to this point.  There is "ImageManager" in the original design doc.  Is this what you are referring to?  Why is the "ImageManager" responsible for interacting with the whole Inventory space?  Need some more words here.
Sotware manager is repo name. I am referring to ItemUpdater. ItemUpdater will use both inventory and entity-manager to get the devices/hosts list.
Does this mean a single one or a new one per device/update type?
new single instance generic for all image types.
'Host' and not "HOST".  It isn't an acronym.
Please update this section to incorporate the Compatibility design.  I would expect something like "Compatible" being the data entry in the manifest.

No.  Let's rely on the manifest.

We need these to be specific to the device being updated.  There are many different CPLD chip models and a huge number of purposes of those CPLDs in a server.  There is no way to take an arbitrary image named "CPLD" and know if it goes on a particular device.

The same goes for BIOS, VR, BIC, ME...
I'm not sure this is a useful section.  These are implementation-specific decisions, so leave it to the implementation of an ItemUpdater to figure it out.
I assume this is related to the Compatible interface? https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/49210
Yes. This is related to Compatible interface.
I'm pretty sure markdown backticks need to be at the beginning of the line and not indented.

If we are launching updates via service files, how do we track completion and report error status?

Where are you expecting the code for all this to live?

Tracking - New D-bus property called completionPercent or isCompleted flag to track the completion status. 

Will explore an alternate for service file logic.
How did the name 'host' come to be here?  What is the relationship between the Activation path names and the proposed systemd service?
Ack. This flash takes care of host image update. Will remove the host since BMC updater not used service file.
I don't see any change here.  Still says 'flash-host-bios'.
Please don't turn service files into another scripting language.
Strike this concept.  There is no value in it.
There is, at a minimum, incorrect verb tense somewhere here.  I don't know what this sentence is suggesting because depending on which verbs I correct I get a different meaning.

Ack. If the field "TargetHosts" is NOT present in the MANIFEST file, then the update is performed in all devices/hosts identified by the ItemUpdater, then the image is removed from disk.

Will change this in the doc.
Hopefully only for un-applied images, right?
What code is doing the listening here?  This paragraph isn't obvious what it is requiring to be done.
Host ItemUpdater code doing to watch/listening if user removes the image manually, we need to remove the object path, clean flags.
Please use proper Compatible strings for this identification.

Hi All, 

 Could you please review this design and provide your comments if any or provide your approval.

Thanks,
Kumar.

There are a number of comments I made in PS7 where you made an "answer" of sorts but I don't see any updates.  If it is clear for me, it probably isn't clear for the next person who reads it either, so we should likely make doc updates for clarity.
Ack. Updated the doc with more detail

I'm not really following how 'Host' is related here.  You've talked earlier about arbitrary device types but then we have 'Host.Updater' here.

I think you should use the word "service" somewhere as this is a new dbus-service you are describing.
I don't understand this or the "the file name" at the beginning of this sentence.

Updated the sentence. The file name here refers to Image file name.

The file name contains an isolated sub-string such as "BIOS","CPLD", "VR", "BIC" or "ME" both upper and lower cases) just identifies the image type.

Isolated sub-string is BIOS, CPLD , BIC etc after the filename with '.' The format of the image.

What is an "isolated sub-string"?  Don't we want these to be exact matches with some known compatibility string?  Otherwise how do you prevent someone from applying a "BMC.Yosemite" onto a "BMC.Tiogapass"?

Isolated sub-string is BIOS, CPLD , BIC etc after the filename with '.' The format of the image.

We have to parse and compare the each element separated by '.'. 
Element is TwinLake and Type is BMC or host. Type and revision needs to be compared with exact match. 

ImageType=com.facebook.Software.Element.TwinLake.Type.Host.Bios.Rev

I don't really understand how this works from a systemd perspective.  Don't we need some way so that a different service is ran for BIOS update vs ME update vs VR update?  But you've put 'bios' as part of the template now, so systemd can only launch a generic 'obmc-flash-software@' service.

How do we handle two different BIOS update methods?  For instance, a system like Yv2/Northdome where you could plug an Intel and AMD compute card into two different slots (in theory.  in practice we don't do this.  we should support it in the software design though.  We do have to deal with this for NICs.)

Different BIOS update is possible with compatible string using type with Rev.

For example : If we wanted to update Bios with two versions 1 and 2 like Bios_1, Bios_2. then, we can use this compatible string and check the type as Host.Bios and revisions as 1 and 2. We compare with exact string match with type and Rev.

ImageType=com.facebook.Software.Element.TwinLake.Type.Host.Bios.1
ImageType=com.facebook.Software.Element.TwinLake.Type.Host.Bios.2

With Different Revisions, we can handle different BIOS methods. Revision number and Type should vary between the different BIOS update methods.

Images can be differentiated and identified by compatible string format.

All Bios update methods are handling using Ipmb commands in Bridge IC. So,BIC accepts only valid format of data for firmware update commands for different cards. The command data is different for each card.

Updated the above in the doc.

We already have Common.Progress.  I don't really know how this solves the issue of tracking the completion of systemd services that we have started in the updater process.

A few things to consider:

- If there is a service kicking off a custom tool for applying an update, don't you want that service to exit once the update is done?  So it will never have Progress.Status = Completed or Aborted because it will simply exit.

- If the service doesn't exit, how do we garbage collect them?

- How do you ensure that two updates are not applied to the same device in close proximity (ie, while one is updating the other one is started)?

- What do we do if the update fails in the middle?  Are any errors reported back to the ItemUpdater?  Or is it expected to monitor for the systemd status on the service it kicked off?

1. Custom flash tool needs to updated to monitor the progress of Completion
continuously. This progress of Completion is calculated based on the total
and completed image size. This Value is updated in the service
"xyz.openbmc_project.oem_firmware_update" with new property.
ItemUpdater can read this progress of completion from this Dbus-interface.

So, custom tool keep on updating the progress in the dbus properties in "xyz.openbmc_project.oem_firmware_update" service. For example : It will update as completion status with 25% or 50% or 100%. 

2. Custom flash tool can be updated with setting timeout option for every
chunk of data sent via Ipmb command. If update is not happening till that
timeout period then we set the status as Aborted.

If the service is not exist for some timeout, it might go to abort status.
if status is aborted, dbus-proeprties can be updated with Abort status.
Itemupdater can remove the images if status is aborted.
  
3. The Inprogress status can avoid the two image updates on same device.
ItemUpdater can activate the images only if that is not in the Inprogress state. 
So, we can ensure that two updates are not applied on the same device.


4. If any errors or update fails in the middle, that status can be updated in the
dbus-properties and based on this ItemUpdater can get the error status from
dbus-properties.

Let's not create a new progress indicator interface, also we shouldn't rely on timeouts. The status of a d-bus service can be monitored via systemd state changes, ex: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt/blob/0cd6d84b0a58a950e691835f3241395d4628a6d4/ubi/flash.cpp#L30
ACK. Will explore more on systemd state changes for d-bus service monitoring and update the design doc accordingly.

How would a user specify that they only want two hosts updated now and two hosts later?
The earlier design proposal had anew Redfish property so that the user could specify which host to update, but that section has been removed (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/37950/3..4/designs/multi-host-bios-update.md).
In this latest proposal seem that the MANIFEST would specify which hosts to update via the ImageType Bios.Rev string. Does that mean that the MANIFEST need to be updated every time the user wants to update a different combination of host instances?

No need to update MANIFEST for every time if user wants to update different host instances. Based on Activation set for hosts, the particular host instances will be updated. 

For ex : if user wants to update 2 hosts, then activation has to be set for those 2 hosts only. 

I will check on the Redfish property to host update and add it in the doc.

Implementation for this design is in progress. Not yet submitted the patches as WIP in gerrit.

Please find the below link for our POC code.
https://github.com/HCLOpenBMC/phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt/tree/ItemUpdaterRefactoring.

Once this design gets approved, will submit the series of patches.
What does "manually" mean in this case, issue a "rm /tmp/images/*" command? Shouldn't any removal be done with a Delete d-bus call?
User can remove/delete the images with D-bus delete call and not with "rm" command.
Ok, the delete call removes the software object path and can clear anything that's needed, there's no need to add a watch for the image file to be removed from the filesystem to take any actions.
Ack. ImageUpdater code is doing image removal and clear the software object. watch/listening is not needed here. Will update this in doc.

Hi All,

Could you please review this design doc and provide your comments if any.

Kumar.
There are still a number of commits from earlier reviews marked "Unresolved".  Please mark them as "Resolved" if you think they have been taken care of.

This is a rather poor design to me.  It means we effectively get very few Progress percentage values.  Is there something better that can be done?

Do we need to provide a dbus API for the subordinate services to be able to report back to the daemon Progress percentages? https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/37950/8/designs/software-update-for-multiple-devices.md

Yes. I think, progress can be updated in the dbus property is fine. Itemupdater can read from that progress dbus property.

Adding a new property to the existing Object.Delete doesn't seem workable because what you're asking for is very specific to the software update routine.  Object.Delete is used outside of update.

Why does the user need any control on this at all?  If all hardware we know of has been updated, wouldn't we automatically delete anyhow?

'AutoDelete' option is might need for below case2. Assuming we have 4 hosts.

Example cases:

1. Delete the images if all the 4 Devices/hosts are updated. (Deleted automatically. use don't have any control)
2. Delete the images if only 2 hosts are intended to update now and 2 hosts are not intended to update anymore.(Somehow user need to specify to delete those 2 hosts which are not updated).
3. Will not delete the images if only 2 hosts are intended to update now and 2 hosts are intended to update later. 

In the case2, user need to specify to delete the hosts via configuration or something. That's the reason we introduced 'AutoDelete' option here.

Hi All, 

Could you please review this patch and provide your comments if any.

Thanks.
Good progress has been made on this.  There are still some issues/comments I'd like to see addressed before moving forward on this Design proposal.

This sentence is confusing.  This seems to contradict the previous statement where the image would only be deleted if the user had updated all four devices/hosts which could be updated.  This statement indicates the image would be deleted if only 3 of the 4 were updated.
Provided below are the implementation steps.

It would be good to better relate which details are needed from the ItemUpdater collected data.  List of devices/hosts is one thing, but I think types of FW to be updated, current versions (both running and to be activated versions) and other details should be documented here.

As with the BIC firmware mentioned below, there may be multiple CPLDs in a server which need to be updated.  These images are different for each CPLD.  Thus, image type probably needs to be more granular so it can be resolved to a particular CPLD device which needs to be updated.

Agree. sub type can be added in the compatible interface for this different or multiple CPLD image. 

Compatible=com.facebook.Software.Element.TwinLake.Type.Host.SubType.GPIO.Bios.Rev

Ex : Host CPLD has power CPLD and GPIO CPLD, sub type parameter can specify the power or gpio CPLD. 

Updated the same in the doc.

One caveat is there is not just a single type of BIC firmware.  The BIC can be located on the baseboard or the main server board and there can be separate BICs on add-in cards.  Thus, there may be as many as 3 different BICs which need firmware updates to be performed on each host/server.

Agree. Same as like different CPLD. we can have Sub Type parameter in Compatible interface to specify the multiple BIC images.

Updated the same in the doc.

...the host details for software updates are retrieved from the inventory.

It would be good to show this example as BIOS instead of CPLD so the comparison of changes required for the same firmware type (e.g. BIOS) can be seen.  I'm assuming you are presenting the single-host type as an example of what is present today and the multi-host as what will be added. Agree. BIOS multi-host example is added instead of CPLD.

How will status of the service be handled if there is an error/update failed on one host when parallel updates are in progress?  It might be best to indicate initially updates would be handled serially but an enhancement to support parallel updates may be considered in the future.

We have an Activation interface for each images. So, whenever images starts Activation property under "xyz.openbmc_project.Software.Activation" is set. 

In parallel update also, multiple Activation interface can be set. If any single image failure, that failure reflected in Activation interface itself. The Error or failure is not reflected in service.

I am a bit confused here about the use of the term 'Activation'.  For Firmware updates in general, activation means the firmware is being moved from a staged to a running state.  Staging the firmware is normally the first step (e.g. copying it down to the device).  Activation is typically a second state which can occur either at the same time as staging or done at a later time.  Activation implies changing the device from running the current firmware image to the newly staged image.  

Can you clarify here and in this section in general whether Activation implies staging or if there is a separate state that needs to be accounted for here.
Here, Activation is pointing to separate state to mentioning about the particular images starts the firmware update or not.  It is not pointing to staging here.

This sentence seems to be missing something.  I believe it means to indicate the systemd service which is invoking the flash tool will have its status changed to failed or inactive status.  However, this isn't clear here.

With the size of some of these images, could the BMC run out of storage if the images are left forever?  Should there be a check to ensure the BMC has enough storage to handle the firmware images somewhere during the process?

Agree.

If "AutoDelete" flag is set as "no" then the existing image will not deleted. If we try to copy new image for FW update, then BMC may go out of storage. 

To overcome this issue, if "AutoDelete" flag is set as "no", the new FW update is not allowed. Such away that the Framework needs to updated to avoid BMC out of storage problem.

extra spaces around the comma between CPLD and BIC.
